all_paragraphs: When I first started my data science internship, I didn’t really know what I was getting myself into.

I had only worked on personal projects up until that point, and I wasn’t at all familiar with what the working environment would be like, the data I would have to work with, and the tools I’d have to use. I was told that strong Python and SQL skills were a requirement for the position, and spent a couple of weeks brushing up on my programming and querying skills. I even took Udacity’s free course (SQL for Data Analytics) to brush up on the syntax and certain important concepts.
In this article, I will break down the experience of my three month data science internship, and tell you everything I learned along the way.
The first couple of days, I started to get familiar with the working environment, company culture, and my team members.
I was briefed on the tools we were to use — AWS, Pyspark, Excel, and Tableau.
Personally, I have never properly used any of these tools before my internship. Most of my data science and analytic projects revolve around Python, Pandas, and a Jupyter Notebook.
However, the learning curve on the technical side wasn’t very steep. AWS was used to collect, store, and prepare data.

I had never used Pyspark before, but its syntax seemed very similar to the Pandas library. Pyspark also has external libraries like Pyspark SQL that allow you to use SQL queries to manipulate dataframes.
Finally, Excel is used for further data manipulation and visualization, and Tableau for data visualization.
I was pretty new to the team, and joined when most of my co-workers were working from home. This made it a little difficult for me to get started with AWS, and I struggled with the installations.
In fact, it took me around three days to get all the installations set up properly on my laptop and get everything to work.
This could have been avoided if I asked for help from the right people straight away, instead of spending hours on my own figuring out how to get everything to work.
I learnt the most important lesson in the first few days of my internship — ask for help when you are stuck.
Another really important thing I learnt during my internship was the importance of having strong communication skills.
Being a query monkey and having strong technical skill isn’t enough. It is important to ask questions such as:
Being able to understand the end to end workflow is important, and you should be able to tie in business requirements with the analysis you are doing.
Nobody really cares about how beautiful your dashboard is if they can’t understand it, and if it doesn’t bring them any closer to solving their business requirement.

Client A sells chocolates. They want to understand their customer base better, in order to know how to position their company and create targeted advertisements to different markets. It is the data team’s responsibility to come up with detailed insights to help them understand their customers better.
Based on the client data available, we take a look at things like customer footfall, demographic data, and customer psychography. We then come up with insights, for example:
The data team does this segmentation, and we derive insights that will be useful to company A to decide how to advertise to different segments of customers.

We build charts and visualizations, and tell a story around the insights we derive from data. The work we do will further be built upon by the business intelligence team, who translate the insights and come up with marketing campaign ideas for company A.
I learnt a lot during my internship experience. In fact, I have learnt more in the past three months than I have in the past three years at university.
This may sound small in comparison to everything else that you need to learn, but is actually super important, especially if you work with data.
I can’t tell you the number of times I never saved files to a proper path, and have had to run the entire analysis all over again.
I was doing my internship and studying in university simultaneously. This meant that not only did I have client requests to work on, I also had university assignments and tests to complete.
I had to be very diligent in maintaining a balance between school and work, and meeting all deadlines on time.

As I mentioned above, business domain knowledge is important to have as a data scientist/analyst. Your analysis needs to provide insights that a stakeholder or client can use to solve a business problem.

Business domain knowledge isn’t necessarily something you need to read up or study (though it would definitely be useful for you to learn it). It is a skill that can be honed over time, with experience.
Finally, I learnt the importance of having good communication skills. As I mentioned earlier, nobody cares how beautiful your chart is if they don’t understand it.
You need to have the ability to break down your findings to non-technical and non-data people.
This means you will need to explain your findings in a way that is so simple and understandable, that even a seven year old can understand it.

I would like to end this article by saying that my data science internship has been an incredible journey. I got the opportunity to work with a team of talented and driven individuals, who guided me every step of the way.
Learn continually — there’s always “one more thing” to learn.
